sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 11800/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr. Andrey Aleksandrovich Pakhtusov (“the applicant”), on 17 January 2010.
2.  The applicant was represented by Mr E. Mezak, a human rights activist practising in Syktyvkar. The Russian Government (“the Government”) were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights.
3.  The applicant complained about the ban on family visits established by Russian law in respect of administrative detainees.
4.  On 17 June 2010 the application was communicated to the Government. The parties submitted written observations on the admissibility and merits.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant is a taxi driver.
6.  On the night of 25 July 2009 traffic police stopped the applicant’s car. Following the applicant’s failure to produce his driving licence and suspecting that it had been withdrawn, police officers took him to the duty unit of the Ezhvinskiy District police station, where he was kept in a cell for administrative detainees until the following morning. A record of the applicant’s administrative arrest was drawn up.
7.  On 26 July 2009 the Justice of the Peace of the Vezhdinskiy Court Circuit of the Ezhvinskiy District found the applicant guilty of driving a vehicle after the withdrawal of his driving licence (an administrative offence under Article 12.7 § 2 of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences) and sentenced him to fifteen days of administrative detention.
8.  On 31 July 2009 the applicant made a written request to the head of the detention unit seeking a family visit. The next day the request was returned to the applicant bearing a handwritten note by the acting head of the detention unit, Mr S., which stated that family visits were not “provided for [by law]”.
9.  On 14 August 2009 the applicant’s representative lodged a complaint with the Syktyvkar Town Court, alleging that the applicant’s right to family life guaranteed by Article 8 of the Convention had been unlawfully restricted.
10.  The police officials filed a written objection, arguing that the Internal Rules governing Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees did not provide administrative detainees with the right to have a family visit.
11.  On 15 September 2009 the Syktyvkar City Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint, having accepted the police authorities’ argument that administrative detainees were not entitled to a family visit under the domestic law in force and that the applicant had been subjected to those limitations of his rights as a negative consequence of the administrative detention.
12.  The applicant’s representative appealed. Relying on the Court’s judgments in the cases of Messina v. Italy (no. 2) (no. 25498/94, § 61, ECHR 2000X) and Vlasov v. Russia (no. 78146/01, § 123, 12 June 2008), he argued that the authorities’ assistance in maintaining contact with close family was an essential part of a detainee’s right to respect for family life. Limitations imposed on the number of family visits constituted an interference with the applicant’s rights under Article 8 of the Convention. Restrictions of that kind could only be applied “in accordance with the law”, should pursue one or more legitimate aims and, in addition, should be justified as being “necessary in a democratic society”. The representative submitted that there was no norm in Russian law imposing restrictions on family visits for administrative detainees.
13.  On 22 October 2009 the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic upheld the City Court’s decision, having reasoned as follows:
“There is no prohibition on family visits for administrative detainees.
...
[At the same time] a refusal to authorise a family visit has a basis in Russian law; however, it should be warranted by circumstances and conditions providing the competent authorities with the right to apply the disputed restriction. Providing lawenforcement bodies with unlimited powers in issues pertaining to fundamental rights could run contrary to the superior role of the law and could result in arbitrary interference with human rights.
In the case under examination, there are no grounds for concluding that the actions of the acting head [of the detention unit of the police station where the applicant had been detained] were unlawful because, having applied for a family visit, [the applicant] had not indicated whom he had wanted to see and what the relationship was between him and that person. If those important details are not provided, the authorisation of a family visit cannot be considered lawful.”
II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
14.  The relevant provisions of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences (no. 195-FZ of 30 December 2001, in force at the time) read as follows:
Article 3.9
“Administrative detention ( административный арест ), a type of administrative sentence, is imposed by a judge in exceptional cases for a limited number of administrative offences and for a period not exceeding fifteen days.”
Article 12.7 § 2
“Continuing to drive a vehicle after a driving licence has been withdrawn is punishable by administrative detention of up to fifteen days.”
15.  At the time of the events, administrative detention was governed by the Regulations on Procedure for Serving an Administrative Detention (adopted by the Governmental Decree no. 726 of 2 October 2002) and by the Internal Rules for Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees (adopted by Order no. 605dsp issued by the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia on 6 June 2000). Both documents were silent on the possibility of family visits for administrative detainees.
16.  On 26 July 2013 the Administrative Detention Act (no. 67-FZ of 26 April 2013) came into force. Article 10 of the Act provided administrative detainees with the right to have an hour-long family visit during the detention period.

events.source_text: On 15 September 2009 the Syktyvkar City Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint, having accepted the police authorities’ argument that administrative detainees were not entitled to a family visit under the domestic law in force and that the applicant had been subjected to those limitations of his rights as a negative consequence of the administrative detention.

events.source_text: The applicant’s representative appealed. Relying on the Court’s judgments in the cases of Messina v. Italy (no. 2) (no. 25498/94, § 61, ECHR 2000X) and Vlasov v. Russia (no. 78146/01, § 123, 12 June 2008), he argued that the authorities’ assistance in maintaining contact with close family was an essential part of a detainee’s right to respect for family life. Limitations imposed on the number of family visits constituted an interference with the applicant’s rights under Article 8 of the Convention. Restrictions of that kind could only be applied “in accordance with the law”, should pursue one or more legitimate aims and, in addition, should be justified as being “necessary in a democratic society”. The representative submitted that there was no norm in Russian law imposing restrictions on family visits for administrative detainees.
events.event_what: argued

events.source_text: On 22 October 2009 the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic upheld the City Court’s decision, having reasoned as follows: “There is no prohibition on family visits for administrative detainees. ... [At the same time] a refusal to authorise a family visit has a basis in Russian law; however, it should be warranted by circumstances and conditions providing the competent authorities with the right to apply the disputed restriction. Providing law enforcement bodies with unlimited powers in issues pertaining to fundamental rights could run contrary to the superior role of the law and could result in arbitrary interference with human rights. In the case under examination, there are no grounds for concluding that the actions of the acting head [of the detention unit of the police station where the applicant had been detained] were unlawful because, having applied for a family visit, [the applicant] had not indicated whom he had wanted to see and what the relationship was between him and that person. If those important details are not provided, the authorisation of a family visit cannot be considered lawful.”
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Komi Republic
events.event_what: upheld the City Court’s decision

events.source_text: II. Relevant Domestic Law 14. The relevant provisions of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences (no. 195-FZ of 30 December 2001, in force at the time) read as follows: Article 3.9 “Administrative detention ( административный арест ), a type of administrative sentence, is imposed by a judge in exceptional cases for a limited number of administrative offences and for a period not exceeding fifteen days.” Article 12.7 § 2 “Continuing to drive a vehicle after a driving licence has been withdrawn is punishable by administrative detention of up to fifteen days.”
events.event_what: imposed administrative detention

events.source_text: 15. At the time of the events, administrative detention was governed by the Regulations on Procedure for Serving an Administrative Detention (adopted by the Governmental Decree no. 726 of 2 October 2002) and by the Internal Rules for Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees (adopted by Order no. 605dsp issued by the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia on 6 June 2000). Both documents were silent on the possibility of family visits for administrative detainees.
events.event_what: governed by regulations

events.source_text: On 26 July 2013 the Administrative Detention Act (no. 67-FZ of 26 April 2013) came into force. Article 10 of the Act provided administrative detainees with the right to have an hour-long family visit during the detention period. FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Declares the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention concerning the denial of a family visit during the administrative detention admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible; 2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; 3. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the Russian roubles at the rate applicable at the date of settlement: (i) EUR 1,000 (one thousand euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage; (ii) EUR 3 (three euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses; (b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points; 4. Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction. Done in English, and notified in writing on 16 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: declared the complaint admissible

events.source_text: The police officials filed a written objection, arguing that the Internal Rules governing Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees did not provide administrative detainees with the right to have a family visit.
events.event: Police officials filed a written objection
events.event_what: filed a written objection arguing that the Internal Rules governing Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees did not provide administrative detainees with the right to have a family visit.

events.source_text: On 15 September 2009 the Syktyvkar City Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint, having accepted the police authorities’ argument that administrative detainees were not entitled to a family visit under the domestic law in force and that the applicant had been subjected to those limitations of his rights as a negative consequence of the administrative detention.
events.event_what: dismissed the applicant’s complaint

events.source_text: The applicant’s representative appealed.
events.event_what: appealed

events.source_text: Relying on the Court’s judgments in the cases of Messina v. Italy (no. 2) (no. 25498/94, § 61, ECHR 2000X) and Vlasov v. Russia (no. 78146/01, § 123, 12 June 2008), he argued that the authorities’ assistance in maintaining contact with close family was an essential part of a detainee’s right to respect for family life.
events.event: The applicant's representative argued based on previous court judgments
events.event_what: argued that the authorities’ assistance in maintaining contact with close family was an essential part of a detainee’s right to respect for family life.

events.source_text: Limitations imposed on the number of family visits constituted an interference with the applicant’s rights under Article 8 of the Convention.
events.event: The limitations on family visits were considered as an interference
events.event_what: Limitations imposed on the number of family visits constituted an interference with the applicant’s rights under Article 8 of the Convention.

events.source_text: Restrictions of that kind could only be applied ‘in accordance with the law’, should pursue one or more legitimate aims and, in addition, should be justified as being ‘necessary in a democratic society’.
events.event: The restrictions were discussed in terms of legality
events.event_what: Restrictions of that kind could only be applied ‘in accordance with the law’, should pursue one or more legitimate aims and, in addition, should be justified as being ‘necessary in a democratic society’.

events.source_text: The representative submitted that there was no norm in Russian law imposing restrictions on family visits for administrative detainees.
events.event: The representative submitted that there was no norm in Russian law
events.event_what: submitted that there was no norm in Russian law imposing restrictions on family visits for administrative detainees.

events.source_text: On 22 October 2009 the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic upheld the City Court’s decision, having reasoned as follows:
events.event: The Supreme Court of the Komi Republic upheld the City Court's decision
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Komi Republic
events.event_what: upheld the City Court’s decision

events.source_text: ‘There is no prohibition on family visits for administrative detainees.’... ‘[At the same time] a refusal to authorise a family visit has a basis in Russian law; however, it should be warranted by circumstances and conditions providing the competent authorities with the right to apply the disputed restriction. Providing law enforcement bodies with unlimited powers in issues pertaining to fundamental rights could run contrary to the superior role of the law and could result in arbitrary interference with human rights.’
events.event: The Supreme Court of the Komi Republic's reasoning on family visits for administrative detainees
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Komi Republic
events.event_what: 'There is no prohibition on family visits for administrative detainees.’... ‘[At the same time] a refusal to authorise a family visit has a basis in Russian law; however, it should be warranted by circumstances and conditions providing the competent authorities with the right to apply the disputed restriction. Providing law enforcement bodies with unlimited powers in issues pertaining to fundamental rights could run contrary to the superior role of the law and could result in arbitrary interference with human rights.’

events.source_text: ‘In the case under examination, there are no grounds for concluding that the actions of the acting head [of the detention unit of the police station where the applicant had been detained] were unlawful because, having applied for a family visit, [the applicant] had not indicated whom he had wanted to see and what the relationship was between him and that person. If those important details are not provided, the authorisation of a family visit cannot be considered lawful.’
events.event: The Supreme Court of the Komi Republic's reasoning on the applicant's request for a family visit
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Komi Republic
events.event_what: 'In the case under examination, there are no grounds for concluding that the actions of the acting head [of the detention unit of the police station where the applicant had been detained] were unlawful because, having applied for a family visit, [the applicant] had not indicated whom he had wanted to see and what the relationship was between him and that person. If those important details are not provided, the authorisation of a family visit cannot be considered lawful.’

events.source_text: II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
events.event_what: II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW

events.source_text: The relevant provisions of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences (no. 195-FZ of 30 December 2001, in force at the time) read as follows:
events.event: Relevant provisions of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences are presented
events.event_what: The relevant provisions of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences (no. 195-FZ of 30 December 2001, in force at the time) read as follows:

events.source_text: Article 3.9
events.event: Article 3.9 of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences is presented
events.event_what: Article 3.9

events.source_text: ‘Administrative detention ( административный арест ), a type of administrative sentence, is imposed by a judge in exceptional cases for a limited number of administrative offences and for a period not exceeding fifteen days.’
events.event: Article 3.9 of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences is explained
events.event_what: 'Administrative detention ( административный арест ), a type of administrative sentence, is imposed by a judge in exceptional cases for a limited number of administrative offences and for a period not exceeding fifteen days.’

events.source_text: Article 12.7 § 2
events.event: Article 12.7 § 2 of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences is presented
events.event_what: Article 12.7 § 2

events.source_text: ‘Continuing to drive a vehicle after a driving licence has been withdrawn is punishable by administrative detention of up to fifteen days.’
events.event: Article 12.7 § 2 of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences is explained
events.event_what: 'Continuing to drive a vehicle after a driving licence has been withdrawn is punishable by administrative detention of up to fifteen days.’

events.source_text: At the time of the events, administrative detention was governed by the Regulations on Procedure for Serving an Administrative Detention (adopted by the Governmental Decree no. 726 of 2 October 2002) and by the Internal Rules for Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees (adopted by Order no. 605dsp issued by the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia on 6 June 2000). Both documents were silent on the possibility of family visits for administrative detainees.
events.event: The governing documents for administrative detention are explained
events.event_what: At the time of the events, administrative detention was governed by the Regulations on Procedure for Serving an Administrative Detention (adopted by the Governmental Decree no. 726 of 2 October 2002) and by the Internal Rules for Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees (adopted by Order no. 605dsp issued by the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia on 6 June 2000). Both documents were silent on the possibility of family visits for administrative detainees.

events.source_text: On 26 July 2013 the Administrative Detention Act (no. 67-FZ of 26 April 2013) came into force.
events.event: The Administrative Detention Act came into force
events.event_what: On 26 July 2013 the Administrative Detention Act (no. 67-FZ of 26 April 2013) came into force.

events.source_text: Article 10 of the Act provided administrative detainees with the right to have an hour-long family visit during the detention period.
events.event: Administrative detainees were granted the right to a family visit
events.event_what: provided administrative detainees with the right to have an hour-long family visit during the detention period.

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event: The Court's unanimous decision is presented
events.event_what: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,

events.source_text: 1.   Declares the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention concerning the denial of a family visit during the administrative detention admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
events.event: The Court declared the complaint admissible and the remainder inadmissible
events.event_what: 1.   Declares the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention concerning the denial of a family visit during the administrative detention admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;

events.source_text: 2.   Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: The Court held that there was a violation of Article 8 of the Convention
events.event_what: 2.   Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;

events.source_text: 3.   Holds (a)  that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the Russian roubles at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event: The respondent State is ordered to pay compensation
events.event_what: 3.   Holds (a)  that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the Russian roubles at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:

events.source_text: (i)  EUR 1,000 (one thousand euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
events.event: The respondent State is ordered to pay compensation for non-pecuniary damage
events.event_what: (i)  EUR 1,000 (one thousand euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;

events.source_text: (ii)  EUR 3 (three euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;
events.event: The respondent State is ordered to pay costs and expenses
events.event_what: (ii)  EUR 3 (three euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;

events.source_text: b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: Simple interest is ordered to be paid on the compensation amounts
events.event_what: b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;

events.source_text: 4.   Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: The remainder of the applicant's claim for just satisfaction is dismissed
events.event_what: 4.   Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 16 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: Done in English, and notified in writing on 16 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

events.source_text: 1. The case originated in an application (no. 11800/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr. Andrey Aleksandrovich Pakhtusov (“the applicant”), on 17 January 2010.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: The applicant was represented by Mr E. Mezak, a human rights activist practising in Syktyvkar.
The Russian Government (“the Government”) were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights.
The applicant complained about the ban on family visits established by Russian law in respect of administrative detainees.
events.event_what: complained about a ban on family visits

events.source_text: On 17 June 2010 the application was communicated to the Government.
events.event_what: communicated an application

events.source_text: The parties submitted written observations on the admissibility and merits.
On the night of 25 July 2009 traffic police stopped the applicant’s car.
events.event_what: stopped a car

events.source_text: Following the applicant’s failure to produce his driving licence and suspecting that it had been withdrawn, police officers took him to the duty unit of the Ezhvinskiy District police station.
A record of the applicant’s administrative arrest was drawn up.
events.event_what: was administratively arrested

events.source_text: On 26 July 2009 the Justice of the Peace of the Vezhdinskiy Court Circuit of the Ezhvinskiy District found the applicant guilty of driving a vehicle after the withdrawal of his driving licence.
events.event_what: was convicted of driving a vehicle after the withdrawal of his driving licence

events.source_text: On 31 July 2009 the applicant made a written request to the head of the detention unit seeking a family visit.
events.event_what: made a request for a family visit

events.source_text: The next day the request was returned to the applicant bearing a handwritten note by the acting head of the detention unit, Mr S., which stated that family visits were not “provided for [by law]”.

On 14 August 2009 the applicant’s representative lodged a complaint with the Syktyvkar Town Court, alleging that the applicant’s right to family life guaranteed by Article 8 of the Convention had been unlawfully restricted.
events.event_what: lodged a complaint

events.source_text: On 15 September 2009 the Syktyvkar City Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint.
events.event_what: dismissed a complaint

events.source_text: On 22 October 2009 the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic upheld the City Court’s decision.
events.event_what: upheld a decision

events.source_text: On 26 July 2013 the Administrative Detention Act came into force.
events.event_what: came into force a law

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
1. Declares the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention concerning the denial of a family visit during the administrative detention admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
events.event_what: declared a complaint admissible

events.source_text: 2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: 3. Holds

a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts...
events.event_what: ordered a payment

events.source_text: 4. Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event_what: dismissed a claim

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 16 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: notified a document

events.source_text: 1. The case originated in an application (no. 11800/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by a Russian national, Mr. Andrey Aleksandrovich Pakhtusov ("the applicant"), on 17 January 2010.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: 2. The applicant was represented by Mr E. Mezak, a human rights activist practising in Syktyvkar. The Russian Government ("the Government") were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights.
events.event_what: represented

events.source_text: 3. The applicant complained about the ban on family visits established by Russian law in respect of administrative detainees.
events.event_what: complained

events.source_text: 4. On 17 June 2010 the application was communicated to the Government. The parties submitted written observations on the admissibility and merits.
events.event_what: submitted written observations

events.source_text: 5. The applicant is a taxi driver.
6. On the night of 25 July 2009 traffic police stopped the applicant's car.

7. On 26 July 2009 the Justice of the Peace of the Vezhdinskiy Court Circuit of the Ezhvinskiy District found the applicant guilty of driving a vehicle after the withdrawal of his driving licence (an administrative offence under Article 12.7 Â§ 2 of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences) and sentenced him to fifteen days of administrative detention.
events.event_what: sentenced

events.source_text: 8. On 31 July 2009 the applicant made a written request to the head of the detention unit seeking a family visit.
events.event_what: request

events.source_text: 9. On 14 August 2009 the applicant's representative lodged a complaint with the Syktyvkar Town Court, alleging that the applicant's right to family life guaranteed by Article 8 of the Convention had been unlawfully restricted.
events.event_what: complaint

events.source_text: 10. The police officials filed a written objection, arguing that the Internal Rules governing Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees did not provide administrative detainees with the right to have a family visit.
events.event_what: filed

events.source_text: 11. On 15 September 2009 the Syktyvkar City Court dismissed the applicant's complaint, having accepted the police authorities' argument that administrative detainees were not entitled to a family visit under the domestic law in force and that the applicant had been subjected to those limitations of his rights as a negative consequence of the administrative detention.
events.event_what: complaint

events.source_text: 12. The applicant's representative appealed.
events.event_what: appealed

events.source_text: 13. On 22 October 2009 the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic upheld the City Court's decision, having reasoned as follows:
14. The relevant provisions of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences (no. 195-FZ of 30 December 2001, in force at the time) read as follows:

15. At the time of the events, administrative detention was governed by the Regulations on Procedure for Serving an Administrative Detention (adopted by the Governmental Decree no. 726 of 2 October 2002) and by the Internal Rules for Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees (adopted by Order no. 605dsp issued by the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia on 6 June 2000). Both documents were silent on the possibility of family visits for administrative detainees.
16. On 26 July 2013 the Administrative Detention Act (no. 67-FZ of 26 April 2013) came into force.
FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
1. Declares the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention concerning the denial of a family visit during the administrative detention admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
3. Holds

(a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 Â§ 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the Russian roubles at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
(i) € 1,000 (one thousand euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
(ii) € 3 (three euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;

(b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
4. Dismisses the remainder of the applicant's claim for just satisfaction.
Done in English, and notified in writing on 16 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 Â§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
